title: High average block time
body:
#### System information

Geth version: 1.5.4
OS & Version: Ubuntu 14.04 64bits

#### Expected behaviour

Average block time should be 14 to 17 seconds.

#### Actual behaviour

Average block time is 28 seconds.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

Private chain running with:
```
 geth \
        --rpc \
        --rpccorsdomain "http://127.0.0.1:8545" \
        --networkid "424242" \
        --targetgaslimit "0x8FCF88" \
        --unlock 0 \
        --password /opt/cocorico/blockchain/password \
        --datadir /opt/cocorico/blockchain/data
````

Did not happen before block ~260000.

#### Backtrace

````
> eth.getBlock(271700).difficulty / eth.hashrate
13.165133403843468
````

 Yet the facts are very different and my calculations based on the logs of the last 10 blocks shows an average of 28 seconds. Other measurements can show an average block time up to 2 to 3 minutes.

That's a 68.79s average blocktime. That's 4x what it should be...
Any idea?

Stupid question, but still...
If I ever let my private chain mine wiht 4 miner threads, difficulty would rise to catch up, right?
Then if I stop then resume mining operations with a single thread, it's expected to have a "4x to high" difficulty. Right ?

> If I ever let my private chain mine wiht 4 miner threads, difficulty would rise to catch up, right?
Then if I stop then resume mining operations with a single thread, it's expected to have a "4x to high" difficulty. Right ?

Yes, indeed.

I have a proposal for a zero miner feature that would be useful solely for (trusted) private networks where the miner would strive to always push difficulty to zero while maintaining 15 sec block times. The idea would be that it should allow mining without eating up even a single core, and also if someone would need ether it would be trivial to mine a few blocks instantly without pushing up the difficulty :)
